comments.commentBody: Increasing the age when seniors can retire might sound like a good idea on the surface but it is neither a good idea nor will it save money in the long run. It will just switch where the burdens are going to lie.  There are not enough jobs in this country to begin with.  The advances in the telecommunications industry have made it fairly easy for greedy employers who want more profits to outsource American jobs to India and other countries. Many Americans are out of work because of it.  Now, if you make the seniors stay on the job longer, what that means in the long run is there will be even fewer jobs for the younger people, because if the elderly don't retire there is less job turnover. So the young people will be even more vulnerable to problems with unemployment than they are now. In addition, although seniors are living longer, they're still suffering from a lot of age-related problems like arthritis and failing eyesight which will not only potentially make them less effective on the job, and that will hurt the people they are servicing in a variety of ways, but the stress of having to keep working longer can make these age-related problems worse, thereby increasing their needs for medical care, and put them into nursing homes sooner instead of later. It really is a short-sighted plan, typical for the Republicans who never think about where they're going until after they've fallen into the hole and taken us along with them, but I would expect more sense from the Democrats.
Does any one think if our wages are half of what is now employers will hire more employees?

The employer tax break might help small and medium businesses. Not sure Nvidia qualifies for that category. Hold on...let's think...no, it sure doesn't.

That said: the employer tax break probly won't amount to a hill o' beans re: job creation, beating the depression, etc.

I still say the $450Billion might as well be divided up proportionately among American households. It'd amount to about $4500 per household on average (far more for a family of 8 and far less for a family of 1 not counting your dog or boyfriend).

Anywho, I'm just sayin that you could spur consumer spendin and whatnot a helluva lot quicker if you just give me a debit card with a few grand on it. Really.

Really.

It would be good if those in Washington would read these comments.  There are some good ideas.  Allen, from Brooklyn is correct when he says that CONSUMERS create the jobs.  Without their purchasing power there would be no market.  The execs who say the plan will not work, are those who need to have their tax cuts from GW rescinded.  Keep the regulations intact.  That is the only way to keep corporations in line.  Make them toe the mark, if they leave to go to China, India, etc., it should cost them plenty through fines imposed for doing so.  It should cost them a huge tax after they leave, to then sell their goods to the American market.

Maybe this so called stimulus will help people looking to work at KFC/McDonalds.
A fortune 500 company doesn't really care if they save a couple of thousand dollars per person through the govt.
They want the best... and if they can get it for cheap, even better!
Obama plan is refreshingly sober and on target.  My firm is hiring and what we need is a solid, thoughtful plan like the President has proposed and not an ill-conceived tea party revolution.

Which "employers" are these? Those with the typical circular GOP/Reaganomics "reasoning"? It didn't work for 35 years. Keynsian programs did--until funds were cut off in 1937. But with this GOP saying "no" to anything, and valuing their power above all else to serve their short-sighted sponsors, they will say no to the voters and the country...and end up having power over a has-been dung-heap of a country.

Hmm. So these executives are saying that tax breaks don't create jobs, having customers with money creates jobs? Why weren't we hearing from them for oh, say, the last 9 months when Republicans were claiming the economy needed more tax cuts for the "job creators"? Oh, I get it, these are tax breaks that President Obama proposes. That's different.

If the program costs $447B and it creates 1.25m jobs (mid range in the 500k to 2M estimate in the article) isn't that $375,600 per job? That seems too much.

Even going with the top figure of 2M jobs, that's $223,500 per job.

Wow! Real business people finally speak up. Businesses hire when they expect more demand or see the economy improving. Is anyone in Washington listening, including the President? No because they have all bought into supply-side nonsense.

One of the things that would help lessen competition for the millions out of work is if the US would temporarily stop importing workers - with visas or not - to the US.  Let's give Americans and US residents the first crack at employment.
All I can say is if President Obama's jobs plan gets past. Employers darn well better get on board or else.
...and, of course, if people aren't working, they aren't buying companies' products, making them prosper, spurring hiring. I know, give everyone a thousand dollars and hope they go out and spent it.
If it doesn't work it will be because it was obstructed by Obama-haters.

I'm not a Michigan fan, and I have at time felt a bit weary of the hype surrounding its football program; and yet, I wish them well this year in the Big 10 (er, 12) When you follow a big time program--in my case Nebraska--it is hard to watch your team go through three or four years of almost complete disappointment with a coach who, for whatever set of reasons, just doesn't gel or fit with the culture of a place. And Michigan vs. Nebraska should be a really good game every year. I think it might well replace the old Oklahoma - Nebraska rivalry in intensity, since there is so much similarity in the style of football and the tradition in these two universities. They are both solidly, quintessentially Midwestern smash mouth teams.

I would agree with Gov. Perry that Social Security is a fraud. I would say, however, that it is an Enron-style accounting fraud rather than a Ponzi scheme. The problem with the program is that it relies upon a massive pile of IOUs held from the off-book accounting entity "Uncle Sam Enterprises". Look at Uncle Sam Enterprises, however, and you see nothing but red ink.

There lies the fallacy of the program: It relies upon paper assets - promissory notes - from an entity that has no ability to make good on those promises.

That of course is not the fault of the program. It is the fault of the government that took the money and spent it (often unwisely) and the citizens that allowed (and often encouraged) this spending to happen.

The unfunded liabilities of Social Security are $17.5 trillion. The unfunded liabilities of Medicare are a mind-boggling $75 trillion. Given the current poor state of the nation's budgetary finances how is this funding gap to be closed? All the discussions and proposed solutions seem to dance around the magnitude of the problem.

I'm afraid the answer is that we can't afford the standard of living we've been promised and have come to expect.
It's called sulking.  They are going to hold their breaths until they get everything they want.  And those who are engaged in this behavior don't want Obama as President.  It's as simple as that.

Stupid business people. The economy is lousy because there is no demand. I don't buy a thing. If you want the economy to pick up you have to have jobs. Instead these Republicans are cutting jobs right and left... government jobs. Cutting government spending makes the economy worse. Throwing money at millionaires won't do a thing either. If those millionaires just paid a tiny bit more, so we could get people back to work.. those millionaires could make lots of money. They are stupid people not to understand that.

I have contacted politicians on numerous occasions since Scwartzeneger's election into California of a solution to both the employment crisis and renewable fuel and filtration of carbon emitions. Not a single one has contacted me back. I have called their offices requesting an audience with them and get no where. Maybe they just want this country to collapse.

The tragedy of the commons, writ large. Also, a classical example of the market not being populated by rational beings.

When a company says: 'I'll hire when the economy gets better and people start spending', it is counting on other companies to hire people, revive the economy, and put paychecks in pockets. It is not, strictly speaking, in any particular company's interest to do hire when the economy is down. But since all companies take this view, no one hires, and the economy continues to stagnate.

Why even listen to them? Pass the law. If no businesses avail of it, fine, federal dollars are saved. However, since it's America, I suspect there are still some businessmen with both sense and wisdom. The former trait will lead them to make sound business decisions, and the latter trait will help them save a country which is heading for economic collapse.

This article clearly illustrates the Keynsian economics. When economy is
growing slowly or stagnant, private companies won't hire because there is no work to do. Government has to step in and spend money that will circulate in the economy to create demand and the jobs eventually.
Anti government attitude in this country is creating impediments at the wrong time. It is high time to debunk Republican mantra of tax and regulations as the cause of slow job growth. so long there is marginal profit earned from additional customer orders,employers will accept the orders and hire people to fulfill them.
Republicans either never worked in the businesses or are big liars.
The major problem now is the stock market gyrations and loud talk on financial netwroks of double dip( another recession). Every doomsayer is having a field day. This will dent consumer confidence and oblige them to shut their wallets more tightly.This a much bigger risk now than any tax or regulation.

Of course! If we want businesses to hire, we have to increase demand for their goods and services -- and the way to do that when monetary policy has reached its limit is for government to hire people or buy stuff. This is elementary. It is obvious. It has been known for 70 years now. But it seems to have passed by the dunderheads in government, who seem intent on recreating the mistakes of Herbert Hoover.
